articles.title: Developer Implements 'Doom' in TypeScript's Type System
articles.description: A curious quirk of TypeScript‚Äôs type system is that it is Turing-complete which has led some developers to implement apps entirely in the type system. One such developer has spent eighteen months producing 177 terabytes of types to get 1993‚Äôs Doom running with them. Ridiculous and amazing in equal measure, he ‚ñ∂Ô∏è explains the project in this widely lauded 7-minute video. üëè
articles.author: Sarah Gooding (Socket)

articles.title: Bun v1.2.3 and v1.2.4 Released
articles.description: The rapid pace of progress on the JavaScriptCore-based runtime is only increasing. v1.2.3 pushes frontend dev server features (run bun ./index.html and all the bundling is done for you). bun init can now be used to create a new React project. Meanwhile, Bun 1.2.4 builds macOS apps 60% faster and macOS executables can now be code signed.
articles.author: Jarred Sumner et al.

articles.title: What is TypeScript? An Overview for JavaScript Programmers
articles.description: You may have noticed esteemed JavaScript developer and author Dr. Axel has been on a TypeScript odyssey recently. Here he does a good job at boiling down the what (rather than the ‚Äòwhy‚Äô) of TypeScript. A handy primer on what‚Äôs going on, even if you don‚Äôt plan to use it, since you'll end up interacting with it somewhere..
articles.author: Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

articles.title: React Libraries for 2025
articles.description: Each year, prolific React blogger Robin updates his post covering his opinionated list of essential React ecosystem libraries. He covers a lot of angles from project creation and package management through to state management, animation, form creation, auth, and i18n.
articles.author: Robin Wieruch

articles.title: Turbocharging V8 with Mutable Heap Numbers
articles.description: The V8 team uses the JetStream2 benchmark suite to investigate performance issues and has implemented a new optimization yielding not just a 2.5x improvement in the async-fs benchmark but in other areas too.
articles.author: Victor Gomes (V8)

articles.title: Subverting Control with Weak References
articles.description: A weak reference differs from a normal reference in that it doesn‚Äôt prevent a referenced object from being garbage collected. Most modern JS runtimes support them and James shows how they can be useful.
articles.author: James Long

articles.title: Svelvet 11: Build Node-Based UIs with Svelte
articles.description: A mature Svelte component library for creating interactive node-based UIs and diagrams. v11 adds the ability to toggle between ‚Äòsnap grid‚Äô and freeform modes for manipulating elements. (There‚Äôs a live demo at the bottom of the homepage.)
articles.author: Open Source Labs

articles.title: React Native 0.78 Released
articles.description: A big release for React Native as it ships React 19 support (which requires some tweaks when upgrading) and some more minor tweaks.
articles.author: Novak, Cucci, Gupta and Cipolleschi (Meta)

articles.title: Random: Seedable Random Number Generator
articles.description: You‚Äôve got Math.random but this library takes things a few steps further with easy ways to create random values of various types and using different distributions (e.g. normal distribution, Bernoulli, Poisson, Pareto and Weibull).
articles.author: Travis Fischer

articles.title: QuickJS Sandbox 2.0: Execute JS/TS in a QuickJS Powered Sandbox
articles.description: QuickJS is a small, embeddable JavaScript engine built by Fabrice Bellard and this extends it to make it easy to run code in an isolated sandboxed environment, along with some basic Node module support and a virtual file system. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Sebastian Wessel

articles.description: ‚≠ê The Chromium team is progressing with shipping the Observable API. This is a big deal, especially for libraries like RxJS.
üìä BenchJS is an online JavaScript benchmarking sandbox worth playing with.
A look behind the scenes at recent progress on the records & tuples proposal for JavaScript (currently stage 2 at TC39). You can play with the feature here.
Windows 95 in Electron is, unsurprisingly, Windows 95 running in an Electron app! v4.0 adds Office 95 and IE 5.5 for some (limited) browsing of the Web.
üìä The results of the State of React Native 2024 survey are out.
Next.js 15.2 ‚Äì Now with a redesigned debugging experience and experimental support for React's new View Transitions API and using the Node.js runtime in middleware.
Astro 5.4 ‚Äì Now with remote image optimization and experimental responsive image support in Markdown.
ESLint v9.21.0 ‚Äì Now with a --ext CLI option to lint files with a particular extension.
Ember.js 6.2, Angular 19.2, Node.js v23.9 (Current)

articles.title: üí¨¬†Comparing Local Large Language Models for Alt-Text Generation
articles.description: With over 9,000 images in need of alt-text, the author turned to AI as a potential way to help add them. This post looks over how 12 LLMs approached the task, and how the accuracy of the output stacks up. The results lead to a question: "Is a 'B'-level alt-text better than none at all?"
articles.author: Dries Buytaert

articles.title: The Web on Mobile
articles.description: The mobile web has been more than capable of standing alongside desktop and native app experiences for some time, but more often than not mobile offerings will often fall short. Jeremy reflects on why this seems to be the case.
articles.author: Jeremy Keith

articles.title: Reimagining Fluid Typography
articles.description: For a while now we‚Äôve turned to relative units (like em and rem) for sizing our text, with the reliable clamp() function being a more recent addition to our tool belt ‚Äî but Miriam has some suggestions on how we can improve things further.
articles.author: Miriam Suzanne

articles.title: A Million Little Secrets
articles.description: Josh has an upcoming course all about creating animations and interactive page elements ‚Äî here he digs into how he created the whimsical landing page for it. He shares the techniques he‚Äôs used that we too can start using in our own work to add some flourish and flair.
articles.author: Josh W. Comeau

articles.title: How to Use attr() in CSS for Columns, Colors, and Font-Size
articles.description: Chris takes a look at the upgraded attr() function, which now supports specifying data types for attribute values, thus enabling more versatile use cases beyond just the content property.
articles.author: Chris Coyier

articles.title: Intent to Experiment for Longer
articles.description: As shared above, Chrome is now moving ahead with CSS if() function support, but Roma thinks Google should pump the brakes and not make any premature moves: ‚ÄúGiven how foundational and crucial these features are ‚Äî I would strongly recommend Google to re-think how they‚Äôre planning to ship these features‚Äù
articles.author: Roma Komarov

articles.title: Rethinking Find-in-Page Accessibility: Making Hidden Text Work for Everyone
articles.description: Did you know about the hidden="until-found" attribute? It‚Äôs not globally supported just yet, but it‚Äôs an accessible way to make hidden text searchable via a browsers find-in-page functionality.
articles.author: Christian Schaefer

articles.title: Better Anchor Positioning with position-area
articles.description: The author praises the position-area property, noting how it‚Äôs more than a shorthand for anchor() and introduces some welcome behaviors that may be surprising.
articles.author: James Stuckey Weber

articles.title: This Page is Under Construction
articles.description: A love letter to fun, personal sites, asking us to ‚Äúplease build your own website‚Äù.
articles.author: Sophie Koonin

articles.title: Why I Like Designing in the Browser
articles.description: ‚ÄúI find HTML and CSS easier to grok than most Photoshop menus.‚Äù
articles.author: Tyler Sticka

articles.title: SuperMarquee: A Modern Marquee Component
articles.description: Note that it‚Äôs not free for commercial projects, but there are demos you can preview that demonstrate the variety of marquees you can generate. There‚Äôs even a visual design tool.
articles.author: superplug.in

articles.title: Svader: Create GPU-Rendered Svelte Components
articles.description: The examples are a good way to get a feel for what this offers.
articles.author: Holger Dal Mogensen

articles.title: BenchJS: A Browser-Based JavaScript Benchmarking Tool
articles.description: No setup needed, just write and run the benchmarks and view the detailed metrics as they run. Includes ESM package support and you can share the results via URL or image.
articles.author: Andrei Neculaesei

articles.title: Accessible Color Palette Generator
articles.description: A useful tool for generating a range of shades (accents, neutral, etc) for a specified color, balancing accessibility, brand identity, and scale. GitHub Repo. Related write-up.
articles.author: Francis Wu

articles.title: Tailwind CSS Grid Generator: Generate CSS Grids Based on Tailwind Classes
articles.description: A simple drag-and-drop grid that you can edit interactively to generate the Tailwind-based code in HTML or JSX format.
articles.author: Oxbow UI

articles.title: trimMiddle: A JS Utility to Shorten Strings Like macOS' Finder
articles.description: Trims a string in the middle rather than the beginning or end, adding an ellipsis by default, which you can change to a different string if desired.
articles.author: Christian Heilmann
